statement.text: Axillobifemoral bypass is an extra-anatomic bypass procedure that provides blood flow from the axillary artery to both femoral arteries without entering the abdomen. This procedure is reserved for patients with aortoiliac occlusive disease who are too high-risk for direct aortic reconstruction. The bypass utilizes a prosthetic graft (typically PTFE) tunneled subcutaneously along the lateral chest wall and abdomen, with a femorofemoral crossover graft to perfuse both legs.
statement.formal: Axillobifemoral Bypass: Axillary artery (1st portion) exposure → Femoral artery exposure (bilateral) → PTFE graft anastomosis (end-to-side axillary) → Subcutaneous tunnel lateral chest/abdomen → Femoral anastomosis (end-to-side or end-to-end) → Femorofemoral crossover | Indications: High-risk aortoiliac disease, hostile abdomen, infected aortic graft

explanation.intuition: When you can't rebuild the main highway (the aorta), you build a bypass road around it. Axillobifemoral bypass takes blood from an artery in the shoulder area and routes it down the side of the body in a plastic tube under the skin, then splits it to both legs. It's like building a detour around a blocked highway - not as durable as fixing the main road, but it works when you can't access the main route.
explanation.key_insight: Axillobifemoral bypass is the quintessential bailout procedure - it's what you do when you can't do the right operation (aortobifemoral bypass). Patency rates are inferior (60-70% at 5 years vs 85-90% for ABF), but the key is selecting patients who truly can't tolerate the bigger operation. It also saves lives in infected aortic graft situations.
explanation.technical_details: Technique: (1) Position patient supine with ipsilateral arm abducted 90°; (2) Expose axillary artery (first portion, medial to pectoralis minor) through infraclavicular incision; (3) Expose both femoral arteries through vertical groin incisions; (4) Create subcutaneous tunnel from axilla along midaxillary line, anterior abdominal wall, to ipsilateral groin; (5) Use long tunneling instrument or tube; (6) Pass 8mm ringed PTFE graft through tunnel; (7) Anastomose end-to-side to axillary artery; (8) Anastomose end-to-side to ipsilateral femoral artery; (9) Create subcutaneous tunnel through suprapubic area to contralateral groin; (10) Anastomose 6-8mm PTFE femorofemoral graft end-to-side to both femoral arteries (or make T-junction at ipsilateral anastomosis). Graft selection: 8mm axillofemoral limb, 6-8mm femorofemoral limb, externally supported (ringed) to prevent compression.
common_misconceptions: Axillobifemoral bypass is as good as aortobifemoral - patency is significantly inferior
Any patient can have this procedure - the axillary artery must have good inflow (check subclavian)
The graft can be placed anywhere under the skin - routing matters to prevent kinking and compression
It's a simple procedure - the tunneling and graft management require careful technique

definitions_glossary.extra_anatomic_bypass: Bypass that doesn't follow normal anatomic vascular route
definitions_glossary.axillary_artery: Continuation of subclavian artery, provides inflow for bypass
definitions_glossary.ringed_graft: PTFE graft with external rings to prevent compression/kinking
definitions_glossary.femorofemoral_crossover: Graft connecting both femoral arteries to provide bilateral perfusion
definitions_glossary.hostile_abdomen: Prior surgeries, adhesions, or conditions making abdominal surgery high-risk

indications: Aortoiliac occlusive disease in high-risk patient (prohibitive surgical risk)
Hostile abdomen from prior surgery, radiation, or infection
Infected aortic graft (staged or definitive extra-anatomic reconstruction)
Aortobifemoral bypass failure with no other options
Limb salvage when endovascular options exhausted
contraindications: Active infection along graft tunnel path
Skin breakdown or ulceration in tunnel area

technique.positioning: Supine, ipsilateral arm abducted 90° on arm board

incisions.axillary: Infraclavicular, 6-8cm below clavicle in deltopectoral groove
incisions.tunneling: May need counter-incision at iliac crest for tunneling

graft_selection.alternative: 8mm body with bifurcated limbs (factory-made axillobifemoral graft)

tunnel_creation.route: Midaxillary line to anterior abdominal wall, avoiding bony prominences
tunnel_creation.instrument: Long tunneling rod or chest tube

steps: Expose axillary artery medial to pectoralis minor
Create subcutaneous tunnel from axilla to ipsilateral groin
Pass ringed PTFE graft through tunnel
Create suprapubic tunnel to contralateral groin

complications.prevention: Adequate inflow check, proper graft sizing, surveillance

complications.management: Antibiotics, possible graft excision with alternative reconstruction

complications.prevention: Careful tissue handling, avoid tension on closure
complications.management: Local wound care, debridement if needed

outcomes.comparison_to_abf: Inferior patency but avoids abdominal surgery

definition.@value: Extra-anatomic bypass procedure routing blood from the axillary artery to both femoral arteries via subcutaneous graft, avoiding abdominal surgery

sources.citation: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery, 9th Edition. Extra-Anatomic Bypass.
Passman MA, et al. Axillofemoral bypass: indications and outcomes. J Vasc Surg.

learning_objectives: Describe the indications for axillobifemoral bypass
Perform the technical aspects of axillobifemoral bypass
Understand the outcomes compared to anatomic reconstruction
Select appropriate patients for extra-anatomic bypass
clinical_pearls: Always check the subclavian artery for stenosis before planning - bad inflow = bad bypass
Use ringed (externally supported) graft to prevent compression
The femorofemoral limb is critical - if it thromboses, you lose one leg
This is a bailout procedure - if the patient can tolerate ABF, do ABF
For infected aortic grafts, this provides extraanatomic flow before graft excision

medicalCode.description: Bypass axillary artery to femoral artery with synthetic substitute
